keyTakeAways: Federal officials, including Customs and Border Protection (CBP) and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), are under judicial scrutiny for allegedly violating a judge's order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal munitions during protests in Chicago.

Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, issued a sweeping order requiring body-worn cameras and limiting crowd control tactics, citing concerns that agents used tear gas without warning and failed to follow her directives.

Officials claim compliance with camera use, stating over 200 CBP agents in Chicago are required to wear body-worn cameras, but the judge remains unconvinced due to reports of tear gas deployment without prior warning.

The Trump administration has faced criticism for allegedly ignoring judicial orders, with officials like Kyle Harvick and Shawn Byers testifying, though the judge demands accountability from higher-ranking officials like Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino.
Protests against ICE actions have continued at the Broadview ICE facility, with over 100 demonstrators gathering and 15 arrests reported on Friday and Saturday in October 2025.
The judge has stated she is not happy with the government’s compliance and will continue to require transparency, including deposing Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino if necessary.
A government attorney previously argued the judge relied on 'one-sided and selectively edited media reports,' but the judge has expressed skepticism of this defense.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Federal officials, including CBP and ICE, are under judicial scrutiny from U.S. District Judge Sara Ellis, an Obama appointee, for allegedly violating her order restricting the use of tear gas and less-lethal force during protests in Chicago. The judge, concerned about reports of tear gas deployment without warning, has mandated body-worn cameras for all agents and requires accountability from key officials. Although CBP claims compliance, the judge remains skeptical, demanding testimony from Russell Hott and Gregory Bovino, who were initially required to appear but are now scheduled for deposition. Operation Midway Blitz, a Trump administration-led immigration crackdown in Chicagoland from September 8 to October 3, 2025, resulted in over 1,000 arrests and sparked sustained protests, particularly at the Broadview ICE facility, where over 100 demonstrators gathered and 15 were arrested. The administration has denied media reports of tear gas use without warning, but the judge insists on full transparency, asserting that failure to provide answers will lead to further legal action.
title: Federal Officials Defend Actions Amid Judge's Probe Into Chicago ICE Protests and Tear Gas Use
